Award.AwardTitle: SIRA Modules for Effectively Engaging Engineers in Ethical Reasoning About Emerging Technologies

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Ethics Education in Science and Engineering award addresses growing calls for ethics as a core competency in engineering education. The fundamental questions addressed by this research are:

(1) What is the impact of a scaffolded, integrated, and reflexive analysis (SIRA) approach to ethical analysis of cases concerning emerging technology on the development of students' ethical reasoning and satisfaction and engagement with ethics education?
(2)What characteristics of this SIRA approach most contribute to change in moral reasoning ability and to student satisfaction and engagement with engineering ethics education?
This will be studied by examining the relationship between graduate and senior-level undergraduate students' participation in and experience of the online learning module and their development of ethical reasoning and satisfaction and engagement with ethics education. The result will be several SIRA modules that will have been piloted in the online format with increasingly larger groups of engineering seniors and graduate students. Their effect will be assessed through analysis of reasoning, interactivity, discourse, and reflectivity.

Broader Impacts: The results of this project will be communicated in engineering education and ethics communities by presentation at professional engineering education, national engineering, and ethics conferences. This will include publishing findings in peer reviewed publications with potential to reach collegiate educators. In addition, the interactive case-based modules will be made available through the NSF-sponsored website for online ethics, Ethics CORE at http://nationalethicscenter.org, and the NAE Online Ethics Center at http://www.onlineethics.org. SIRA learning modules with established assessment instruments that have proven to be effective in developing ethical reasoning abilities for engineers will be an attractive option for embedding into a wide variety of engineering courses and curricula across disciplines and within a variety of engineering programs at both undergraduate and graduate levels.

ProgramReference.Text: ETHICS EDU FOR SCI & ENG PROG

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our multidisciplinary team of engineering, communication, and ethics educators has developed an innovative and interactive learning system for enhancing the ethical reasoning skills of engineering students. This new learning system we call PRIME Ethics, Purdue Reflective & Interactive Modules for Engineering Ethics, has been shown to increase students' satisfaction and engagement with their ethics education. We first addressed the need for enhancing ethical reasoning by developing a coherent approach to ethical reasoning within engineering with a principle-based approach, Reflexive Principlism (RP), which addresses both macro and micro ethics. Secondly, we created a pedagogical framework of Scaffolded, Interactive, and Reflective Analysis (SIRA) that extends beyond case-based analyses. Third, to better engage students in ethics education we developed five interactive, online learning modules, deliverable in a hybrid format for stand-alone course or embedded curricular applications. Additionally, we developed two new assessment tools: the Ethics Transfer Case, to measure students’ ability to transfer skill in ethical reasoning, and the SIRA scale, to measure students’ satisfaction and engagement with several aspects of the learning system. To disseminate this work, we have published several articles based on research findings, hosted a workshop for engineering ethics educators, and begun sharing the system with ethics educators at other institutions for testing its applicability in their programs.

 

Each of the five modules in the PRIME Ethics learning system challenges students to move through six stages of reflective analysis. Collectively, the diverse range of cases developed to date expose students to diverse stakeholder perspectives, conflicting value claims, and contemporary ethical problems. The first module teaches the foundational Reflexive Principlism approach to ethical decision-making that students apply to all subsequent cases. The subsequent four modules are case-based and include a historical engineering disaster case study (Kansas City Hyatt skywalk collapse), a case evaluating conflicts of interest in diagnostic biomedical device development, a case analyzing the just delivery of healthcare on a global scale (pediatric heart valve technology), and an environmental engineering ethics approach to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Together these cases explore a range of ethical questions across multiple engineering disciplines while focusing on the specification and balancing of the principles of respect for autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence, and justice. The diverse range of ethical, epistemic, social, and systemic issues encountered throughout these cases has proven particularly impactful for enhancing engineering students’ ethical reasoning skills.

 

We have designed, delivered, and tested this PRIME Ethics learning system in several teaching modes, from residential courses, to hybrid in-class/on-line, to a primarily asynchronous online format. In all modes self-paced individual learning offered in a multimedia context is complemented with highly interactive small-group discussions. For the multimedia context of these modules we partnered with an innovative educational media company (In The Telling) to build an interactive system of integrated resources embedded within actual student deliberations.  As an ultimate goal for each case, students continue deliberations in small groups of four to five students to attempt to resolve a complex ethical issue.

 

In summary, the findings of our project provide empirical support for the efficacy of Reflexive Principlism (RP) combined with a SIRA pedagogical framework as an innovative approach to successfully engage engineering students in ethics education and enhance their ethical reasoning skills. This project contributes data supporting a new knowledge and understanding of how engineers think about the ethics of their practice. The project also has developed a unique learning system built on this new knowledge that has been tested and shown to increase ethical reasoning of engineering students. The PRIME Ethics learning system, supported by Reflexive Principlism as a theoretical reasoning approach and driven by the SIRA framework as a pedagogical process, engages diverse engineering students in ethical decision-making in a satisfying and intellectually robust way. The learning system contains highly interactive media and deliberations that encourage active engagement with learning, uses complex ethical cases that connect directly to engineering practice addressing both micro as well as macroethical issues, and can be delivered in multiple digital formats both locally and globally. The ethical reasoning that future engineers learn and practice can readily be applied to other cases within their engineering practice and leadership as their professional lives develop and thus have a broad impact on the global development and implementation of new technologies. Already the PRIME Ethics learning system is having a broad impact in that nearly 40 ethics educators explored the modules for their own programs at an American Society of Engineering Education workshop in 2015, several additional universities are now using the modules, one team member has been invited to run an ethics course tutorial for the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, University of Montenegro, in June of 2017, and in 2016, the NAE recognized our research as an exemplar of engineering ethics education in a national publication “Infusing Ethics into the Development of Engineers”.
